metadata.title: Effect of nano silica particles on Interfacial Tension (IFT) and mobility control of natural surfactant (Cedr Extraction) solution in enhanced oil recovery process with nano - surfactant flooding

sections.text:
AC CE
PT ED
nano particles have received increasing attention in oil upstream industry in the last decade. In this communication, Cedr Extraction (CE) as natural surfactant and nano silica were used. The influence of CE and nano particles on Interfacial Tension (IFT) of aqueous phase was studied using Pendant Drop method. The effect of nano particles on mobility control was then investigated using the results of core flooding. By increasing the surfactant concentration from 0 to 10 wt%, it was observed that the IFT of kerosene and aqueous phase reduces from 35 to 11.9 mN/m; increasing the nano silica concentration from 0 to 2500 ppm causes the reduction in IFT value from 15.5 to 13 mN/m. Using pH method for investigating the CMC point of different concentrations of CE solution indicates that 5 wt% of CE in 100,000 ppm brine represents the CMC point. Repeating the above methods for different concentrations of nano silica in 5 wt% of CE solution shows that 1000 ppm of nano silica represents the CMC point. Adding nano silica causes increasing oil recovery from 53% from flooding by CE solution to 74%, in sandstone core.
Keywords - Critical Micelle Concentration (CMC); Nano Silica; Zizyphus Spina Christi; Natural Surfactant; Interfacial Tension (IFT); Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR).

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Exploration of new giant oil fields is a low opportunity option and small oil fields are
uneconomic and expensive in costs. Therefore, oil companies prefer to produce trapped oil in reservoirs during primary and secondary oil production phases. Surfactant flooding is one of the tertiary oil recovery or enhanced oil recovery (EOR) methods in order to producing trapped oil and increasing oil recovery. Surfactant flooding is one of the chemical EOR methods. The chemical EOR methods typically include polymer, surfactant, alkaline-polymer and alkalinepolymer-surfactant flooding (1-5). Most of companies use petroleum based surfactants which cause environmental issues. Some reports are about sustainable surfactants which are applied in ecologically safe drilling fluids (6). Cedr Extraction (CE) is a natural and biodegradable sugar based surfactant. It is produced from the leaves of Zizyphus spina-christi (Cedr tree which is a tree in the Middle East countries like Iran, Jordan, Egypt and …) (7-10). There are many factors that are important in choosing suitable surfactant for chemical flooding. Price and accessibility of the surfactants are the most effective factors in selecting an economic and logic surfactant. Cedr Extraction (CE) can be economically usable for chemical enhanced oil recovery because of low cost and environmentally safe (11).
Foam as an EOR agent can improve sweep efficiency by mobility control, reducing
injected gas mobility and redirecting gas streams; therefore using foam can reduce gas production or gas coning in production wells. Foam can turning aside acid into target area, like damaged or low permeability zones; so can improve acidizing. It has wide application in upstream industry like drilling, cementing, wellbore clean up and fracturing, because it has

important and effective properties like desirable rheology properties, low density, capability to transport solid particles and economically aspect (12, 13).
Nano technology is used rarely in upstream industry. But in recent years, some studies
have indicated the positive influence of application of nano particles in reservoir engineering like smart water, foam stability, wettability alteration and IFT reduction (14, 15). For an effective surfactant or nano displacement, it is essential that the concentration of used solution be above the critical micelle concentration (CMC). CMC is vital for influence of surfactant or nano solutions on IFT and oil recovery (16).
Mobility control is an action to reduce the frontal instability which causes early water
breakthrough, reduction in recovery and loss in efficiency. It is one of the most effective parameters in any flooding program which can be achieved by using chemical EOR like surfactant and foam injection. These methods can modify the wettability and change the relative viscosities and permeabilities of displacing and displaced fluids (17, 18). In the present work, we have studied the effect of nano silica particles on IFT and mobility control of natural surfactant solution as detailed in the followings:

sections.heading: 2. Experimental Equipment and Method
sections.text:
First, surfactant solutions (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10 weight percents of Cedr Extraction in
brine) were prepared. The concentration of brine was 100,000 ppm. Mixtures were prepared using an accurate analytical balance (Sartorius ENTRIS64-1S Analytical Balance, Capacity: 60g,
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
Uncertainty: ± 0.0001g). In order to mixing surfactant and brine, a magnetic stirrer (HJ Magnetism Mixer) was used. After finding the CMC of CE and brine solution, as explained briefly in the followings, the CMC of CE, brine and nano silica solution was studied. For this purpose, several solutions were prepared. In the solutions, the concentration of CE was equal to the CMC which was obtained in the previous step. The concentrations of nano silica were 500, 1000, 1500, 2000, 2500 ppm. An ultra-sonic stirrer (Hiescher UPSOH) was used for dispersion of nano silica in surfactant solutions.
In order to finding the CMC, a set of pH measurements were used. In order to measure
the pH, a Tenway 3510 pH meter (Uncertainty: ± 0.003) was employed. By plotting each set of the pH results vs. surfactant concentration and finding their intersection, the CMC was obtained.
One of the interfacial tension analysis methods is shape analyzing or Pendant Drop
method [19]. This method is accurate enough for studying the interfacial tension of fluid/fluid in a wide range. For this purpose, the images of liquid drops are digitized and then by using Laplace equation, the value of IFT is determined [19]. Kerosene was used in IFT measurements as oil phase (viscosity = 1.3 cp, density = 0.8 g/cm 3 @ at room conditions) and Toluene was used for cleaning the apparatus (viscosity = 0.59 cp, density = 0.867 g/ cm 3 @ at room conditions). Figure 1 (a) shows a schematic of the equipment (VIT 6000, Fars EOR Technology Co.) which was used to measure the IFT of surfactant aqueous solution and kerosene. During the experiment, the pendent drop cell was filled with kerosene and then the transfer vessel was filled with surfactant aqueous solution. The pendant drop equipment, like other interfacial tension equipment, should be clean in order to obtain high quality and reproducible results. Herein, the needle used for hanging the drop should be well cleaned and moving of the interface over the outer surface of the needle should be avoided.

The next step was core flooding with selected surfactant concentrations and injection
flow rate. Core flooding gives a lot of data, such as pressure drop, water saturation, etc [20]. These data were processed and used in studying the mobility control of foam and nano foam injection [20]. Schematic of core flooding apparatus (Core flooding system, Fars EOR Technology Co.) is shown in Figure 1(b). Briefly, a core flood system is a system in which a fluid (gas or liquid) flows through a core sample at controlled pressure and temperature conditions and measures or monitors flow parameters. The main part of a typical core flood system includes: core holder (Hassler), fluid accumulators, constant temperature oven, back pressure regulator and data acquisition and test control system.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
A method of CMC determination is solutions pH measurement, as mentioned earlier. The
values of solutions’ pH lie in two intersected lines. The point of intersection indicates the CMC point. As Figure 2 (a) shows, 5 wt % concentration represents the CMC point. For nano solutions, as seen in Figure 2 (b), the intersection of the matched lines lie on 1000 ppm nano concentration, therefore, we chose the 1000 ppm of nano silica in 5 wt % CE and 100,000 ppm brine solution as the CMC point.
As mentioned earlier, pendant drop method was used to measure the change of IFT
between kerosene and aqueous phase due to increasing the concentration of Cedr Extraction. The IFT values for the kerosene-Cedr Extraction-brine system were plotted against the surfactant concentration and shown in Figure 3 (a). As CE concentration increases from 0 to 10 wt %, IFT

value decreases from 35 to 10.9 mN/m. Figure 3 (b) shows the results of IFT measurement by increasing nano silica concentration. As seen, increasing nano concentration from 0 to 2500 ppm causes a reduction in IFT value from 15.58 to 13 mN/m. As indicated, increasing nano silica concentration in CMC of CE solution has a little effect on IFT. This happens while increasing CE concentration has noticeable effect on IFT.
Figure 3 (a) shows the oil recovery of nano-surfactant flooding for sandstone. Recovery
becomes 74 % after 1.2 pore volume injection of nano solution. In Figure 3 (b), pressure drop increases from 630 psi, at start time, to 2788 psi at breakthrough time; then decreases to 2155 psi at the end of flooding. The pressure drop diagram of nano-surfactant flooding is sharper than CE flooding and as mentioned earlier it means that more better emulsification has occurred. Figure 3 (c) shows the fractional water flow curve of nano-surfactant flooding in sandstone. Average water saturation in nano-surfactant flooding is 0.64 which is more than CE flooding.
Figure 4 (a) is the plot of recovery factor vs. injected pore volumes for all coreflooding.
Ultimate recovery factor of waterflooding is 38%; by adding natural surfactant to aqueous phase, the recovery factor increases from 38% to 53%. This enhancement is continued by adding nano silica to the surfactant solution in the third coreflooding and recovery factor increases from 53% to 74%. Figure 4 (b) is the plot of pressure drop vs. injected pore volume. As mentioned earlier, pressure drop plot can indicate whether emulsion is formed or not. As seen in Figure 4(b), pressure drop increases considerably as CE and nano silica are added to the aqueous phase. This happens because of emulsion formation by adding natural surfactant to the water phase. It can be concluded that forming stronger emulsion will cause steeper pressure drop trend. Another method for investigating the coreflooding displacement efficiency is coreflooding fractional water flow curves analysis. This analysis can provide saturation distribution through the core and

its wetting state. Through the assessment of fractional water flow equation, which was used to plot Figure 4(c), gravity and capillary forces effects are neglected. Figure 4(c) illustrates the influence of adding natural surfactant on fractional water flow curves. In this study, the application of fractional flow curve analysis was used to investigate the effect of natural surfactant and nano silica on recovery. As Figure 4 (c) shows by adding surfactant and nano silica the average water saturation increases, which causes more oil recovery at breakthrough time. Adding surfactant and nano silica to the solution causes residual oil saturation to decrease and thus shifting the fractional flow curve to the right. The decrease in residual oil saturation with increasing surfactant concentration is an indication of increasing oil recovery. Shifting in fractional water flow curves to the right side of horizontal axis indicates the wettability alteration with changes in surfactant concentration in aqueous phase. Considering a homogeneous wettability through the core sample, shifting to the right indicates the rock surface becoming more water wet. Using surfactant causes decreasing in residual oil saturation and increasing in average water saturation. By adding nano silica residual oil saturation does not change, but average water saturation increases and the fractional water flow curve shifts to the right and the shape of cure becomes less steep, which means strong emulsion is formed, more stable profile is created and rock becomes more water wet.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, the effect of adding nano silica to the CE surfactant solution was studied. It
was shown that by increasing the surfactant concentration, the IFT reduces and by increasing the nano silica concentration, the IFT decreases. The oil recovery in sandstone significantly

increases as the surfactant is flooded in nano-surfactant flooding. By adding surfactant and nano silica the average water saturation increases, which causes more oil recovery at breakthrough time. By using nano silica strong emulsion is formed and more stable profile is created.
